diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,50 @@
+#pragma once
+
+#include <torch/nn/module.h>
+#include <torch/nn/rnn.h>
+#include <torch/tensor.h>
+
+#include <ATen/ATen.h>
+
+#include <vector>
+
+namespace torch { namespace nn {
+
+// This is largely just a proof-of-concept of the interface.
+class LSTM : public torch::nn::CloneableModule<LSTM> {
+ public:
+  LSTM(long input_features, long state_size)
+      : CloneableModule<LSTM>("LSTM"),
+        weights_(at::randn(
+            torch::CPU(at::kFloat),
+            {3 * state_size, input_features * state_size})),
+        bias_(at::randn(torch::CPU(at::kFloat), {3 * state_size})) {
+    register_parameters({{"weights", weights_}, {"bias", bias_}});
+  }
+
+  std::vector<torch::Tensor> forward(
+      const std::vector<torch::Tensor>& inputs) override {
body: I wouldn't say that's how it works with Python, because the interpreter is actually doing all the unpacking and size checking for you, and this is the only problem I see with this approach. Such things are notoriously error-prone in C++, and as @goldsborough noted we can't rely on structured binding.
body_html: I wouldn't say that's how it works with Python, because the interpreter is actually doing all the unpacking and size checking for you, and this is the only problem I see with this approach. Such things are notoriously error-prone in C++, and as @goldsborough noted we can't rely on structured binding.
body_text: I wouldn't say that's how it works with Python, because the interpreter is actually doing all the unpacking and size checking for you, and this is the only problem I see with this approach. Such things are notoriously error-prone in C++, and as @goldsborough noted we can't rely on structured binding.
